body.p:
Louisville Nov. 2nd 1863.
His Excellency
Govr. Bramlette --
The woman Mrs Cosden who presents a petition to you for the pardon of her husband is very poor, has infant children, and we believe is an honest and religious woman --
Her husband was indicted for stealing meat & potatoes & some other things from a flat boat. There were some doubts about his guilt in our minds and he was compelled to go to trial without a witness.

The Jury found him guilty & Fixed his term
in the Penetentiary at one year.

His wife is anxious to obtain his release -- Her Petition is well signed. The two persons owning the property said to have been stolen are among the signers. Their names are William Wadell & Thomas O'Hern
Mr. Turner who made the arrest also signed the petition --
If you can pardon him it ^will^ gratify the friends of the unfortunate lady who presents the petition.

Most Respectfully
Baird & Price
Attos at Law
